Tensions over Chinese takeovers on national security grounds are not new, of course. What is different this time is how widespread the opposition is, including in some countries like Australia and the U.K. that traditionally have been more sympathetic to China.
“We’re seeing an unprecedented level of political backlash globally against Chinese investment and in particular Chinese acquisitions,” said Thilo Hanemann, an economist with the New York-based Rhodium Group, who tracks capital flows worldwide.
The flash points are proliferating. Billion-dollar Chinese investments in a Royal Philips NV unit and computer disk maker Western Digital Corp. collapsed this year amid concerns that the U.S. would block them on national security grounds. German lawmakers have expressed concern over Chinese investments in Kuka AG, with the government there unsuccessfully trying to find a European buyer for the robot maker (para 9-10).

We've really only had one observation of a fatal air incident in the South China Sea area due to military actors, which is the instance in March 2001. Assuming that the most likely scenario for another mid-air incident is between the US and China, then that suggests a probability on the order of 1/5600, assuming the US flies through the area every day. China has been stepping up it's aerial activities and aggression in the area recently, I seem to be able to recall recently news of 2 close calls of similar incidents between the US and China air power projection. Even a ten fold increase in the observed risk would only mean a roughly 0.2% chance of some similar incident to happen. The probability of a purposeful military operation that causes human casualties is likely significantly less than 1%, as it does not appear to be in anyone's strategic interests to do so. The interaction between coast guards, like the incident with the Indonesian coast guard's capture of a Chinese fishing vessel, seems to be the most likely mode for some interaction to lead to a fatality. A European Maritime Safety Agency report for 2013 shows that there were 75 fatalities with 2782 ships involved. Each incident may have involved more than one fatality (this includes the grounding of a ferry off the coast of Italy that claimed 25 lives) but also more than one ship may have been involved in a single incident. If those two adjustments cancel, then we get a guess of just under 3% probability of a fatal incident occurring from some sort of a ship to ship interaction. Given that fishing ships are constantly trolling the area (both legally and illegally), the opportunity for some sort of confrontation seems high (perhaps occurring on a daily basis), though the chance of a ramming like the one this March is likely significantly lower than that. If we guess there are somewhere between 2 and 3 incidents of a ship to ship contact from now till the end of the year, that gives a probability that one of these will end in a fatality between 5 and 8%. Call that 6.5%. Plus 0.5% for the chance of an aerial incident plus all other less likely scenarios combined and 7% seems a decent guess.

China's power projection into the South China Sea has become increasingly bellicose and it's rhetoric increasingly aggressive. The opportunity to open a dialogue in March at the nuclear summit in Japan was passed over and there seem to be few opportunities in the coming months to seek better coordination. It is unlikely in the extreme that an intentional lethal confrontation would arise, however China does have a history of engaging in erratic and risky behavior. Any lethal confrontation is most likely to arise from a miscalculation by the individuals involved in operations in the area. For example the mid air collision of a Chinese fighter with a US spy plane in 2001 was most likely due to the reckless behavior of the Chinese pilot. More recently China has been known to ram free fishing vessels that have been captured by Coast Guards operating in the South China Sea (most notably Indonesia). With the introduction of China's new, larger, and armed Coast Guard vessels, their aggressive tactics are likely to continue and the chance for an accident to occur is meaningful.

Break the question into South and East
South: I counted 7 instance of encounters involving China from 2009 to 2015, so 1 encounter per year on average. Using Poisson distribution to describe this process, that is 62% probability of 1 or more encounters (0.96yr to deadline), but let’s just consider the case of 1 encounter. Looking at the past 7 encounters, all of them have the potential to evolve into a lethal confrontation, so I put the probability of next one becoming a lethal one as 10%, just because it feels right. There is also a probability of un-intentional event causing 3+ death, call it 1% (maybe refine it later?). Aggregate all of these, the probability of lethal confrontation in South China Sea = 62%*10%*99%+1%=7.1%

Increasing social and economic internal pressure in China will lead to greater reliance on nationalism and external enemies by the Party to maintain order. The basic problems are well known, in my opinion these include: public and private debt; restructuring the SOEs; rebalancing the economy; land grabs and corrupt local authorities; control of the equity and currency markets; the expanding anti-corruption purge, its targets and effects; capital flight; lack of international engagement beyond investment flows, and no substantial or reputable friends (e.g. Russia, North Korea, Cambodia, Pakistan, Myanmar has left, Venezuela might be leaving); fear of containment; and an inability to accept a multi-power and multilateral world. A less obvious factor might be 'peak stuff' in the industrial economies, which could impact exports of consumer goods while emerging economies are in recession and internal demand is still weak.
I think many of these chickens will be coming home to roost in 2016, and authoritarian regimes under pressure tend to be aggressive, this is one side of my high probability. Note this is not a 'China collapse' scenario, its more like a 'rough patch with consequences'.
The other side of the scenario is possible actions by one or some of the other littoral states. There are several wildcards in play here, including: Vietnamese arms acquisitions and increased capabilities (particularly the submarines); progress of the Philippine case against China in the Hague; the Taiwanese election on Jan 16 and the effect of a pro-independence result, especially if the KMT loses the legislature as well as the presidency; increased maritime surveillance by these, and by Malaysia and Indonesia, will be seen as provocative by China as it attempts to enforce its imaginary boundary. The escalating number and intensity of fishing disputes between China (using their fishing fleet for geopolitical purposes), Vietnam and the Philippines, creates further opportunities for a military or coastguard response to a major clash. A Vietnamese fishing boat was reported as sunk by a Chinese 'vessel' last September.
I do not think there will be a direct confrontation with Japan or the US. However, China has created the conditions for conflict in the South China Sea, where it clearly has no interest in diplomatic solutions. While continually testing the resolve of these other countries by incursions, China may be forced by its own rhetoric to respond with force to an attempt to enforce an EEZ.

Historically speaking, military-to-military confrontations in the South and East China Seas have been exceedingly rare. Digging in to the Correlates of War's militarized interstate dispute dataset (http://www.correlatesofwar.org), I could only find a handful of incidents that would satisfy (or come close to satisfying) the conditions laid out in this question:  

- 2001: a Chinese pilot died after colliding with a U.S. spy plane (though this wouldn't quite meet the 3 fatality threshold)
- 1988: ~70 Vietnames sailors died after Chinese and Vietnamese forces clashed over Johnson South Reef 
- 1974: ~70 sailors died as China seized the Paracel Islands from Vietnam  

Given the low baseline for military-to-miitary clashes in the South China Sea, I don't think its likely that we will see a planned military engagement in the South China Sea before January 2017. Though with tensions on the rise and significant military activity in the area , there's always a chance for accidents (like the 2001 collision between Chinese and US planes).
While China is aggressively expanding its island territory as a way to claim sovereignty using the waterways around it, I believe that negotiations will rule over fighting.

People expecting violence in the South China Sea in the near term do not understand China's view of itself in the world, or Chinese culture.  The Chinese see themselves as the middle kingdom, and while it is smaller than it once was, Chinese leadership has the patience to wait till the right moment to seize back lost territory and then some.  The current climate is one of upheaval in Asia and the U.S. is backing out of a global leadership position.  They are expanding now because they see very little resistance to doing so, other than some empty statements from U.S. officials and President Obama.  The Chinese prefer to expand without force, until it is sufficiently positioned such that force becomes irrelevant.  That is the basis for the base they have built.  It is unlikely that they will harass any neighboring countries or actors in any significant way, and will instead build up their presence to wait for the right time.

The US demonstration was not on the Chinese timetable.  A physical confrontation will not occur until they decide to have one.  Two months will not provide enough time for them to position themselves for one.

In the course of 20 months, China has reclaimed 17 times more territory than other claimants have in the past 40 years (http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/08/21/us-southchinasea-china-pentagon-idUSKCN0QQ0S920150821#wf6CUKSF8CM75cLB.97). There has been no significant push back until last week when the United States conducted it's Freedom of Navigation Operations (FONOP). Although there was no military confrontation, this could help stymie Chinese operations. 
One reason there would be no lethal confrontation next year is that other Asian claimants appear unwilling to have a military confrontation with China. Recently, there was no military confrontation when China sent an oil rig to drill close to Vietnam and the situation was relatively quiet when China evicted the Philippines off the Scarborough Shoal (http://www.economist.com/news/asia/21677241-america-challenges-china-temperature-rises-south-china-sea-hot-water).
With U.S. forces increasing their presence in the Middle East, the United States would do what it can to mitigate a crisis from escalating.
Provocation would likely occur from other claimants such as the Philippines or Vietnam both of which haven't used force against China in the past two years. U.S. FONOP helps to alleviate tensions felt among the claimants who are worried about China.
